ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Robert Buchowski
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Robert Buchkowski
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Robert Buchkowski
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Rob
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Rob Buchkowski

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Robert was a fantastic TF. He was always available to help, even outside of office hours, and was very helpful with projects.
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Readily available to help with homeworks and issues that arose during coding. Well-prepared to teach discussion and/or lecture sessions when necessary.
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  I didn't interact with Rob too much throughout the course, but whenever I did he seemed incredibly helpful and very knowledgeable. One of the best TAs I've had.
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Rob was great. The only issue was not enough personalized office hours, especially towards the end of the semester.

Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Rob was an exceptional TA. He made himself very available to students outside of the classroom and was able to provide clarification to concepts learned in class in a way that made the material more accessible to students. Rob also provided strong support when students were using R software and was able to help troubleshoot students projects with them. I undoubtedly gained much more from this class because of Robs ability to provide students with quality feedback and support.

Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Rob was an extremely accessible TA, making himself readily available for homework help during office hours, while always being available to answer questions. He is a good lab lecturer, and was able to explain the technical aspects of modeling clearly. I have no major criticisms of his teaching.
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Very available and patient in explaining challenging material.

Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Rob was a great TA-- he was very organized and helped us learn a lot. Given the level of the workload, it would have been good for him to have more scheduled office hours, or even a second TA. This was a really difficult class, and I think a second person to explain concepts would be helpful.
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  did a good job helping with homework. was evasive when asked about specific goals for the final project.
Instructor: Robert Walter Buchkowski  Rob was great. He knew the material very well and always did his best to accommodate as many people as possible when assistance was needed.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The material of this course was incredibly interesting and useful, however the pace was a bit too fast for me and I think several other students in the class. Since I lacked experience using R - the assignments took 10x longer to complete than for someone with R experience. This made it very frustrating at times because assignments took way longer than they needed to be completed.

To me, the real value of this course was as a theoretical ecology course. Given that it was taught in FES, I feel that the class in general was expecting more emphasis on the applications of the content to conservation. While there was effort to incorporate this material into the curriculum, I feel it may have been to the detriment of the scientific rigor of the information presented. Perhaps in the future it would be beneficial to teach this course jointly with EEB to encourage more students with strong interests in ecological modeling to take the course.

The course was very fast paced and concepts were not always clear. Assignments were not straight forward, and required much more time than what students have available for a 3 credit class. This led to frustration.

Question 11: The theory that provided the context to the dynamical equations was clearly taught but the mathematics behind the differential equations was not always clear. Question 15: The course is very valuable to students with similar interests as my own as it provides tools to understand ecological models and provides students the opportunity to experiment with building their own model, giving students a deeper level of understanding.
The course was a solid introduction to modeling and theoretical thinking in ecology. No major criticisms.

The instructor presented a wealth of useful and detailed knowledge about ecosystem modeling. The course is really an amazing trove of highly advanced information on current thinking in ecology. I really got a lot out of it. The instructor appears to be a bit frustrated however, and at times wasn't sensitive to the low level of mathematical rigor some students were familiar with. I think, for some students, some basic review of calculus at the beginning of the course could be fruitful - either in class or as a homework assignment to get people up to the point where they need to be.
The layout of the course was a survey of modelling theories. Some theories were highly technical/hard to understand with such a brief overview.

This was a really good class, with great coverage of interesting ideas. However, the material could have been more clearly presented-- I didn't always have a good understanding of how all the different concepts related to one another, or how what we were learning in one week related to what we had previously learned. It also would have been helpful if we had moved more slowly through the material.

An example. During the masters colloquium you sat in on five student presentations. After Lindas presentation you raised you hand to ask a question. You proceeded to belittle Linda, her study, her methods, and the discipline of social science in general. You didnt ask a question you only criticized the study and anyone associated with it. The take away; If only everyone was a smart as me the world would be a better place. To be clear I am not defending the presentation, which was poor. I wanted to point out that you are overly emotionally invested in your discipline. To the extent that you put down a masters student in front of a whole auditorium just to toot your horn. Everyone in attendance saw that you were acting like an insecure asshole. The problem of being overly invested in you discipline extends to this class. If your lecture ventured ever so slightly from your core subject area, the authors, the journal, and the general public are subject to a diatribe describing how wrong headed they are in comparison to you.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The introduction to esoteric material was generally handled very well and addressed to a beginner.
The material, Os's lectures, *some* of the assignments including the term paper though I wish I'd had more time and more R skills to do a better term paper.
Development of an independent project to address a question of our choosing.
I thought Os did a consistently good job of making mathematics approachable and intuitive. There is a need for classes like this in the biological sciences.
Learning how to use R (although technically the learning process was more self-guided than taught). It would be fantastic to have more support with R.

The best aspect of the course was being able to connect theory to mathematics in a way that previously I had not been able to. Gaining an introduction to R was extremely helpful as I will continue to use it in my studies. Learning about the history of ecological theory was also very useful in understanding how the field has grown into what it is today.

The modeling project was the best aspect of this course, as it required extensive thought about your study system. This in turn put you in the mindset of successful modelers, facilitating the understanding of their thinking.
Incredible depth and diversity of knowledge shared.
Connecting the mathematical theory to ecological theory

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More time spent on the mathematical methods such as stability analysis.

I think the lab should be an actual lab in a computer room where we work through the R script for certain assignments or useful processes together. It would have made the labs much more productive and educational.

The homework often times consisted of tweaking pre-written code, which I think led many students to be unprepared to actually write a program from scratch. I think the development of a project should b e incorporated into earlier assignments to make sure students are learning how to program from scratch.
It might have been helpful to do a bit more instruction with R and use the language more extensively on the homeworks.
Time-management, support for students, slower pace.

I think the crossover of the material and the R software needs to be improved further. The lab section of the course was not very structured and I think that would be an ideal time to provide a more formal introduction to R and the ways that we will use it for the course. There was a wide range of skill levels in the class in terms of their familiarity with R and the accessibility of the math foundations for assignments. Any ways to even out students skill levels whether it is through having prerequisites or holding an R tutorial during the lab section would be very helpful.
There could be more purposeful labs. Most labs were just there for time to work on homework with TA help. Using that time instead to tackle mini-projects would be useful.

I think it would be helpful to students in the class if labs were used to work linearly through the textbook for modeling in R. Students not familiar with programming struggled a lot. A 'playing with models' approach is suggested in the course, but the course itself doesn't really live up to this kind of teaching approach. I do not believe the instructor programs in R, but that is fine - students could just read and follow with the textbook and essentially 'teach themselves' this way. This is of course the notion of the final project, but the final projects would probably be more advanced if the first 2/3 of the course were more focused on the basics of modeling (it is conceptually, but some students need to learn how the programming happens - plus that can make it more fun). Also - the final project, in class final, and an additional paper all occurred within 5 days of each other - and before reading week. This seems an excessive amount of work for the last week of classes. Projects could just as easily have been due during reading week.

Variations among students with regards to their ability to use R made it hard to gauge what was expected of us for the final assignment. I felt that my model was very simple compared to other students' because of my limited ability with the software.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There could have been more structured lab sections.
See above.
I feel like often times the lab sections were unnecessary and the information could have either been covered in lecture or through email.
Labs could seriously be improved. The time should be used to teach R, and for hands-on tutorials of how to run the models.
It could be improved by providing a better connection between the material learned in class and the R software.

Lab section exercises at times were supportive, and at other times digressed. The homework assignments had more busy work than is really useful - students in this course could be more engaged by exploring various simple models. This was part of the course and lab, but could be enhanced.

The relationship between lab and lecture was quite effective, although I thought that the combination of homeworks and the final project was too much. The homework assignments were helpful to my learning of the material, but took a lot of time to do, and didn't leave enough time to focus properly on the project.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course fits well into my studies and that is why I ended up taking it despite being hesitant about the amount of work I knew it would be.
Gaining a broader understanding of mathematical ecology.

The course fits well into my program and my future ambitions. It has allowed me to better understand scientific literature, the power of models and the diverse ways that you can display ideas. I feel more confident in my ability to understand ecological material and I see the skills learned in this class being able to translate pretty directly to my research and future work.

I am interesting in better understanding theory in ecology. Math has always been my biggest academic weakness, and this course did a good job at making that side of ecology more accessible/understandable to me.
Great course for me, lots of good additional information on dynamical systems and their application to ecology / env science.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to at least understand how dynamic models are constructed and used, and perhaps how to build them myself.

See above. Also I have mostly avoided quantitative courses at F&ES (not purposefully) so I thought it would be good to do something more quantitative / math-related. Also, Os is an excellent instructor and I wanted to take another course with him because I knew I would learn a lot.
I took this class to be able to understand dynamical systems and ways of explaining and modeling these systems.
See Question 20.
To learn more about dynamics of ecological systems.
I was considering using the course to help frame my summer research experience.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.

Yes and no. Yes, because I feel like I learned several new skills, and no because I thought I would be better at R by the end. I feel like I still need a lot more instruction in R to become comfortable with the program.

Solid foundation in modeling ecological processes using analytically and simulated approaches. I did not gain the same amount of familiarity with coding in R as I thought I would going into the course.
In a word, yes. I was very pleased with the class and what I learned.

Overall yes, I feel I can now better understand systems theory and have skills to begin approaching modeling these interactions. I was not expecting the course to be so heavy in math and this was surprising and very challenging to me. However, I think the class was very valuable in the way that students are better able to understand ecological literature that involves differential equations.
The course has made me more competent in understanding mathematical models, while increasing my proficiency in R. So yes.
Yes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Working as a group is absolutely necessary to solve these complex problems, with people who have different math skills and interests.

Group work was a major advantage to the assignments in this class. Working in a group allowed students to be able to use each others skills and understanding to problem solve. Group work on the assignments provided a much more robust understanding of the material than I would have gained if I had worked on my own.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Make sure you have time outside of class to devote to making sure you understand the more complex subjects.
Do all the R exercises early, or take an R class before or concurrently with this one. It will accelerate your learning and make assignments much easier.
Start working on the project early in the semester and use the homeworks as opportunities to practice doing different things in R to then incorporate into your project.
It is only worth it if you see yourself using ecological models in the future. Other more theoretical courses may be better if you want to strengthen knowledge of ecology.

I would say in order to get the most our of this class, having an introduction to R and a basic understanding of calculus and differential equations would be very helpful. But that if you are looking to learn how to begin modeling system interactions and understanding ecological systems in a more theoretical way this course is great to gain that knowledge.
Be prepared to think hard and invest time in your modeling project. That is the most important part of this course.
It's a lot of work and you need to stay on top of it. This can be a very rewarding course, but you have to take personal responsibility to make it so,

This is a very helpful course, but it is a really large time commitment. To get the most out of this course, you really need to devote a lot of time to it. And without a background in calculus, it is really difficult to understand the material in this course.
don't
